statement.p:
Suppose that W is a subspace of \real^4 with basis
\wvec_1=\fourvec{-2}22{-4},\hspace{24pt} \wvec_2=\fourvec{-2}35{-5}.
What are the dimensions \dim W and \dim W^\perp?
Find a basis for W^\perp.
Verify that each of the basis vectors for W^\perp are orthogonal to \wvec_1 and \wvec_2.

Consider the matrix A = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp -2 \amp -2 \\ 1 \amp 3 \amp 4 \\ 2 \amp 1 \amp -2 \end{bmatrix}.
Find \rank(A) and a basis for \col(A).
Determine the dimension of \col(A)^\perp and find a basis for it.

Suppose that W is the subspace of \real^4 defined as the solution set of the equation
x_1 - 3x_2 + 5x_3 - 2x_4 = 0.
What are the dimensions \dim W and \dim W^\perp?
Find a basis for W.
Find a basis for W^\perp.
In general, how can you easily find a basis for W^\perp when W is defined by
Ax_1+Bx_2+Cx_3+Dx_4 = 0?

Determine whether the following statements are true or false and explain your reasoning.
If A=\begin{bmatrix} 2 \amp 1 \\ 1 \amp 1 \\ -3 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix}, then \xvec=\threevec{4}{-5}1, is in \col(A)^\perp.
If A is a 2\times3 matrix and B is a 3\times4 matrix, then (AB)^T = A^TB^T is a 4\times2 matrix.
If the columns of A are \vvec_1, \vvec_2, and \vvec_3 and A^T\xvec = \threevec{2}01, then \xvec is orthogonal to \vvec_2.
If A is a 4\times 4 matrix with \rank(A) = 3, then \col(A)^\perp is a line in \real^4.
If A is a 5\times 7 matrix with \rank(A) = 5, then \rank(A^T) = 7.

Apply properties of matrix operations to simplify the following expressions.
A^T(BA^T)^{-1}
(A+B)^T(A+B)
[A(A+B)^T]^T
(A + 2I)^T

A symmetric matrix A is one for which A=A^T.
Explain why a symmetric matrix must be square.
If A and B are general matrices and D is a square diagonal matrix, which of the following matrices can you guarantee are symmetric?
D
BAB^{-1}
AA^T.
BDB^T

If A is a square matrix, remember that the characteristic polynomial of A is \det(A-\lambda I) and that the roots of the characteristic polynomial are the eigenvalues of A.
Explain why A and A^T have the same characteristic polynomial.
Explain why A and A^T have the same set of eigenvalues.
Suppose that A is diagonalizable with diagonalization A=PDP^{-1}. Explain why A^T is diagonalizable and find a diagonlization.

This exercise introduces a version of the Pythagorean theorem that we'll use later.
Suppose that \vvec and \wvec are orthogonal to one another. Use the dot product to explain why
\len{\vvec+\wvec}^2 = \len{\vvec}^2 + \len{\wvec}^2.
Suppose that W is a subspace of \real^p and that \zvec is a vector in \real^p for which \zvec = \xvec + \yvec, where \xvec is in W and \yvec is in W^\perp. Explain why
\len{\zvec}^2 = \len{\xvec}^2 + \len{\yvec}^2,
which is an expression of the Pythagorean theorem.

In the next chapter, symmetric matrices---that is, matrices for which A=A^T---play an important role. It turns out that eigenvectors of a symmetric matrix that are associated to different eigenvalues are orthogonal. We will explain this fact in this exercise.
Remember that we can write \xvec\cdot\yvec = \xvec^T\yvec. If A is a matrix, explain why \xvec\cdot (A\yvec) = (A^T\xvec) \cdot \yvec.
We have seen that the matrix A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 2 \\ 2 \amp 1 \end{bmatrix} has eigenvectors \vvec_1=\twovec11, with associated eigenvalue \lambda_1=3, and \vvec_2 = \twovec{1}{-1}, with associated eigenvalue \lambda_2 = -1. Verify that A is symmetric and that \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are orthogonal.
Suppose that A is a general symmetric matrix and that \vvec_1 is an eigenvector associated to eigenvalue \lambda_1 and that \vvec_2 is an eigenvector associated to a different eigenvalue \lambda_2. Beginning with \vvec_1\cdot (A\vvec_2), apply the identity from the first part of this exercise to explain why \vvec_1 and \vvec_2 are orthogonal.

Given an m\times n matrix A, the row space of A is the column space of A^T; that is, \row(A) = \col(A^T).
Suppose that A is a 7\times 15 matrix. For what p is \row(A) a subspace of \real^p?
How can help us describe \row(A)^\perp?
Suppose that A = \begin{bmatrix} -1 \amp -2 \amp 2 \amp 1 \\ 2 \amp 4 \amp -1 \amp 5 \\ 1 \amp 2 \amp 0 \amp 3 \end{bmatrix}. Find bases for \row(A) and \row(A)^\perp.
